Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(2) Summary

The technical aspect of APIs has been widely discussed with description languages such as Swagger/OpenAPI. The non-functional aspects are harder to formalize, but can also benefit from a framework in which information can be represented and used. The idea of "API Labels" is equivalent to that of standardized labeling systems in other product spaces, for example for food or for machinery. There often is a framework in place that allows users to understand key aspects of the product. This framework focuses on areas that are important and helpful to make an initial product selection. In the API space, numerous standards and best practices have evolved how APIs can be described and/or documented. This presentation provides an overview of the existing approaches, how to use them, and proposes an additional layer on top of which API labeling becomes more unified, and thus more useful.

(12) Why Do Labels Work?

Goal: Information about all/many products in large landscapes.

Non-goal: Every possible detail about every single product.

  • Simple/simplified description of important product aspects
  • Supported across large sets of products (sometimes even across categories)
  • Defined/assigned/verified/certified by a trusted third party

(14) Labels: Sharing + Loose Coupling



Why API Labels? Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(15) API the APIs

If you want to say something about your API, say it through your API.
  • Configuration/description/documentation as code
  • Accessible to tooling and automation
  • Separate representation and label semantics


Why API Labels? Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(16) Better Descriptions ⇒ Better Search and Use

  • Google just (September 2018) launched Google Dataset Search [https://toolbox.google.com/datasetsearch]
    • It is based on dataset descriptions [https://www.blog.google/products/search/making-it-easier-discover-datasets/] which are based on schema.org [https://schema.org/]
  • Public description and search helps aggregators (and their users)
  • Private description helps internal management and landscaping


Why API Labels? Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(17) API Label Scenarios

  • API labels are not intended to replace API descriptions
    • Descriptions are more detailed and complex
  • API labels as a way to expose/share information internally
    • Managing labels types/values and trust is relatively easy
  • API labels as a way to expose/share information publicly
    • Managing labels types/values and trust becomes more challenging


Why API Labels? Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

The API Label Value Space Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(24) API Label Types

  • Label types can be registered or extension label types
  • Registered label types are managed in an open API label type registry [https://github.com/API-Labels/API-label-registry]
    • Registered types have well-known names that are simple strings
  • Extension label types can be used by anybody with no registration required
    • Extension types have self-describing names that are URIs


The API Label Value Space Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(29) Home Documents for HTTP APIs [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-nottingham-json-home]

{
  "api": {
    "title": "Example API",
    "links": {
      "author": "mailto:api-admin@example.com",
      "describedBy": "https://example.com/api-docs/"
    }
  },
  "resources": {
    "tag:me@example.com,2016:widgets": {"href": "/widgets/"},
    "tag:me@example.com,2016:widget": {
      "hrefTemplate": "/widgets/{widget_id}",
      "hrefVars": {"widget_id": "https://example.org/param/widget"},
      "hints": {
        "allow": [
          "GET",
          "PUT",
          "DELETE",
          "PATCH"
        ],
        "formats": {"application/json": {}},
        "acceptPatch": ["application/json-patch+json"],
        "acceptRanges": ["bytes"]
      }
    }
  }
}
  • home.json


A Recipe for API Labels Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(30) Finding Labels 

  "api": {
    "title": "Example API",
    "links": {
      "author": "mailto:api-admin@example.com",
      "describedBy": "https://example.com/api-docs/",
      "labels": "https://example.com/labels.json"
    }
  • home-labels.json (line 2-8)
{"labels": {
  "API": {
   "version": "1.3.42",
   "SPDX-license": "ADSL",
   "http://example.com/privatelabeltype": "some label value"
}}}
  • labels.json

(33) Related Work

  • Pivio [http://pivio.io/] for service documentation and discovery
  • APIs.json [http://apisjson.org/] for describing API operations
  • OpenAPI Info Object [https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.1.md#infoObject] and possible extensions
  • RAML User Documentation [https://github.com/raml-org/raml-spec/blob/master/versions/raml-10/raml-10.md/#user-documentation] and possible extensions


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(34) API Labels: Next Steps

  • Decoupling labels from specific API styles and descriptions
  • Collect use cases and patterns for using API labels
  • Converge on a format and establish a registry for shared label types


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(35) Additional Resources

  • API-Labels [https://github.com/API-Labels] organization on GitHub
    • label-format [https://github.com/API-Labels/label-format] repository for the label format
    • API-label-registry [https://github.com/API-Labels/API-label-registry] repository for the registry of API labels
